snippet.textDisplay:
I don't want to sound to like a troll, but personally I didn't like Lost Odyssey very much despite being a huge JRPG fan. I didn't like the characters both for character design and their personalities (Kaim's kids were especially annoying to me), the music was so-so (at least by Uematsu standards) and the gameplay wasn't exciting either. I don't think it's a bad game, but the reputation of being the best JRPG of that generation is heavily overblown, in my opinion.
On a side note, I do like this track though.
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't want to sound to like a troll, but personally I didn't like Lost Odyssey very much despite being a huge JRPG fan. I didn't like the characters both for character design and their personalities (Kaim's kids were especially annoying to me), the music was so-so (at least by Uematsu standards) and the gameplay wasn't exciting either. I don't think it's a bad game, but the reputation of being the best JRPG of that generation is heavily overblown, in my opinion.
On a side note, I do like this track though.

snippet.textDisplay: Same, actually. The best way I can describe it is that it does nothing wrong, but does nothing right at the same time. Everything from character designs, to world building, to the battle system, were all solid, but just so unremarkable. A shame really, I had hopes that it would be its generations "Rogue Galaxy" in terms of being a hidden gem.
snippet.textOriginal: Same, actually. The best way I can describe it is that it does nothing wrong, but does nothing right at the same time. snippet.textDisplay: Imagine what would have happened if Hironobu Sakaguchi, Nobuo Uematsu and the rest of former Square people that formed Mistwalker, had stuck around for Final Fantasy XIII? It would have probably been like this. I think their awesomeness was channeled into this game. I know that people left the company for one reason or another, but imagine what FFXIII could have been like if the people that helped create the series were able to have some input on what is considered to be the worst game in the main numbered Final Fantasy games.
snippet.textOriginal: Imagine what would have happened if Hironobu Sakaguchi, Nobuo Uematsu and the rest of former Square people that formed Mistwalker, had stuck around for Final Fantasy XIII? It would have probably been like this. I think their awesomeness was channeled into this game. I know that people left the company for one reason or another, but imagine what FFXIII could have been like if the people that helped create the series were able to have some input on what is considered to be the worst game in the main numbered Final Fantasy games.

snippet.textDisplay: Yeah Blue Dragon is a very good game, I can't recommend it enough:) It's very similar to Lost Odyssey because it's made by the same company, they're both turn based RPGs, Lost Odyssey has a ring system while in Blue Dragon they summon their shadows that take the form of a mythological being that gives them extra skills. Both games have a beautiful soundtrack composed by Nobuo Uematsu:D I found the story very good but don't expect a mature, dark story and atmosphere like in Lost Odyssey. While Blue Dragon can have its dark moments too it's a light hearted story with beautiful artwork by Akira:) Sorry if it was too long but I really love Lost Odyssey and Blue Dragon.

snippet.textDisplay:
@BrokenMoonStudios I think you're right on that one: I had an xbox but I barely played it and despite owning vesperia and this (and eternal sonata) I didn't see too many other games on it, which is a shame.


However I do mean it when I say that back then turn style rpgs were suddenly becoming "too old" for some reason and this made most devs shift their games into a mix of turn-based and action that MANY TIMES wouldn't work (Ni no Kuni, White Knight Chronicles, Final Fantasy 13 and Eternal Sonata comes to mind). 
If you have a goddamn bar to wait before attacking it's NOT action: it's turn-based disguised as action (at least in my opinion)


I'm just glad that those horrible hybrids are now over and we get proper action rpgs (ys, tales or Shining resonance) or proper turn-based rpgs (persona, digimon cybersleuth)

snippet.textDisplay: FF7 was okay, but hardly what I'd call "setting the bar".  It was 3D, that was IT.  That's all everybody raved about.  Not the spikey-haired emo guy, not the effeminate bad guy with long silver hair, just that it was in 3D.  FF6 had a better story, better characters, and even today still looks better despite being 2D.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nope, FF7 was and still is one of the greatest JRPG's to date. It set the bar in graphics, style, music and as far as I'm concerned, story. That's not to say that all other games were no good before or after FF7, just that it was a new take on what an RPG could be, on how to tell stories and a fantastic world without the traditional fantasy settings.
If you don't agree, that's fine, but to me you kind of sound like you're just trolling. Cloud was, and still is, one of the greatest heroes of our age, and emo is taking it quite a bit too far, I think. I've played and replayed it, and I don't think he's all that emo, not if you look at the whole picture. Sure, he's whiny in the beginning with all the "pay me"-stuff, but I don't think we'd be calling you an emo if your only true rolemodel turned his back on you, killed everyone you know and love and then went on a killingspree with the ultimate goal of destroying the entire planet. I think we'd be calling you one tough SoB for just being sad and angry, being able to interact with people at all. There's a difference between being emo and actually being hurt, IMO.

snippet.textDisplay: Agreed that TLS had some technical problems. As you mentioned, the game had some frame rate/lag issues but I kind of attribute much of that to the power of the Wii. I wouldn't mind a little more polish to the battle system myself. It offered plenty of different elements(stealth, first person, command, gathering, etc) but adding more specials, attack moves, and/or magic spells would be a nice touch. Overall though, gotta say I had a blast and enjoyed every battle vs wanting to run at times in LO.

snippet.textDisplay: I agree that the story/characters in LO were great, but I preferred them in TLS. I don't know why, but I found them more engaging and the story more worthwhile, in my opinion, but Lost Odyssey was still great in that department. However, I am sorry to say, but I personally did not care for the combat in TLS. It was unique and fun at times, but there are a lot of graphical and presentational issues (Lag, framerate drops, etc), as well as bizarre control schemes. This is just my opinion, though.
